channel.title: Does anybody want to make a website with me?
channel.description:
I'm looking to produce a sort of portfolio and was wondering if anybody wanted to develop, design it with me.
This will be responsive and it'll be done ground up. I don't want to use any frameworks. Trying to minimize all JavaScript but still maintaining a dynamic website.
Prefer to work with a novice (or anybody interested) so that they can learn from this, I already am a good designer and am far capable of doing something this trivial on my own however I just need company and somebody to work help with design. This is still open for everybody.
I don't need anybody doing php or anything of that crap because I'm going to use rails to handle everything.
It would be great if your motivated and active.
Just message me if you want to make something with me.
Edit:[b] I only use iMessage or Google hangout.[/b]

item.title: Does anybody want to make a website with me?
item.dc:creator: @Not_a_bot Not_a_bot
item.description:
@Not_a_bot wrote:

[quote=“Death Style, post:33, topic:544179”]I’m all about SPA and have written a few for automation apps. I just don’t like how AngularJS is sending HTML with parts to parse over instead of just all or nothing.

I leave dynamic content empty (e.g. ). A script makes the browser create elements, parse variables, and attach their listeners before they are added to the page.

In AngularJS you send HTML with ng- attribute tags to indicate they need listeners. Plaintext {{ variables }} are also present. The browser loads the script to parse the DOM and scans over these elements, attaching listeners and replacing {{ variables }} with their actual value, after they are already present on the page.

I’m not going to argue which is the better method, I just think the first is cleaner, doesn’t clog up the DOM with unnecessary attributes, and in the event something fails the user isn’t looking at a bunch of {{ variables }} and instead has empty content seemingly waiting to load.[/quote]

Fair enough. Have you given directives a try? You could reduce the clutter by switching some of the ng attributes by using custom elements to define behavior (obviously not entirely). It also gives the benefit of having reusable components in the case you want to define the same behavior elsewhere in your application. As for empty content, I’d think as long as you call your data source before the view is completely rendered you generally shouldn’t run into this issue (in this case, your controller should be calling this at compile time) unless the network is slow.

item.dc:creator: @Not_a_bot Not_a_bot
item.description:
@Not_a_bot wrote:

[quote=“Death Style, post:28, topic:544179”]It’s not the browser’s responsibility to parse content either.

If you are going to rely on the browser to parse {{ 2 + 3 }} as 5 then you’re already indicating you don’t mind the browser playing a role in generating the content. I would just go the full mile and pass DOM elements as smaller pieces of information for the browser to generate with a framework since I’m expecting it to parse content anyway.[/quote]

You’re correct in saying it’s not the browser’s responsibility to populate content, however most modern browsers are powerful enough to do this out of box anyway. I disagree with trying to go the extra mile though to ensure content is delivered, with reliability you’re going to see a drop in performance when you want to scale. Think of how many times you would need to create your blocks of content for each page view and how much processing power is wasted trying to render the page each time. It’s painfully slow and redundant, which is just as bad as a broken page.

I think you’re missing the point of Angular and it’s underlying concepts, rather than creating an essay as to why their design works, I will link you to their wiki page to explain their design goals.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AngularJS#Philosophy

item.dc:creator: @Not_a_bot Not_a_bot
item.description:
@Not_a_bot wrote:

[quote=“Death Style, post:24, topic:544179”]A dynamically created page is parsed before sent to the browser. I don’t think the browser should be performing the initial parse, only dynamic content afterward. If the script failed to load you wouldn’t see what’s expected. Plus it leaves an ugly view source page.

If you’re relying on the browser to parse initial content why not just dynamically create the DOM instead? Just my two cents.[/quote]

wat?

The browser’s only responsibility is to parse the DOM not populate your content… regardless if the script loads or not. AngularJS only injects these variables if the DOM has been loaded and the framework has been initialized. If you’re going to make a huge assumption that end-user has it disabled (which likely won’t happen), you probably shouldn’t be using a JavaScript reliant framework in the first place to serve your content…
